column17: List types of images and non­imaging data provided
Report on the completeness of the data (e.g., number of subjects where all types of imaging, demographic, and behavioral data is available)

Specific instructions on how to gain access. Specifically mention whether application must be vetted for particular intended research use (e.g. to preclude multiple users investigating the same question), or whether a research collaboration must be established
Confirm that the ethics board of the host institution generating the data approves the sharing of the data made available
Clarify any constraints on uses of shared data, for example, whether users downloading the data also need ethics approval from their own institution
Provide URL to documentation, and specify its scope (e.g. worked examples, white papers, etc.)
Report the format of the image data shared, e.g. DICOM, MINC, NIFTI, etc.
Data organization structures, including Data Dictionaries and Schemas. Is the software using an established ontology?
Availability of in-resource visualization of the imaging or non­imaging data
How, if at all, data are de-identified
Availability of detailed provenance of preprocessing and analysis of shared data
Ability of a repository to work in a multi-database environment, availability of API’s and ability to connect to analysis pipelines
Mechanisms available for constructing queries on the repository (e.g. SQL, SPARQL)
How users can check version of downloaded data and compare it to the current version at a later time
